0.0: The song of songs which is Shlomo’s.
0.1: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, for your love is dearer than wine.
0.2: Like the fragrance of good oils, your name is like flowing oil; therefore young maidens love you.
0.3: Draw me, we will run after you; the king has brought me into his chambers, we will be glad and rejoice in you, we recall your love more than wine, they loved you sincerely.
0.4: I am black, but comely, daughters of Jerusalem; like the tents of Kedar, like the curtains of Shlomo.
0.5: Do not look upon me [with contempt] that I am so black, for the sun has tanned me; my mother’s sons were incensed against me, they made me keeper of the vineyards, [but] my own vineyard I did not watch.
0.6: Tell me, you whom my soul loves, where do you graze your flock where do you rest your flock at noon; for why should I flit about around the flocks of your companions?
0.7: If you do not know [you who are the] fairest of women; go forth in the footsteps of the sheep and pasture your kids near the dwellings of the shepherds.
0.8: To steeds in the chariots of Pharaoh I have likened you, my beloved.
0.9: Your cheeks are comely with rows of gems your neck with [pearl] necklaces.
0.10: Circlets of gold we will make for you with spangles of silver.
0.11: While the king was at his table, my spikenard gave out its fragrance.
0.12: A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me, between my breasts he shall lie.
0.13: A cluster of henna is my beloved to me in the vineyards of En-gedi.
0.14: Behold you are beautiful, my beloved, behold you are beautiful; your eyes are like doves.
0.15: You are handsome, my beloved, most handsome; indeed our bed is fresh.
0.16: The beams of our houses are cedars, our panels are cypresses.

1.0: I am a rose of Sharon a rose of the valleys.
1.1: As a rose among the thorns, so is my beloved among the daughters.
1.2: As an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the sons; in its shade I delighted and sat, and its fruit was sweet to my palate.
1.3: He brought me to the banqueting-house, and his banner is raised over me in love.
1.4: Sustain me with dainty cakes refresh my bed with [the scent of] apples; for I am lovesick.
1.5: His left hand was under my head and his right would embrace me.
1.6: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim by the gazelles and the does of the field; that you do not cause hatred nor disturb this love while it still pleases.
1.7: The voice of my beloved! Behold he comes; leaping over the mountains, skipping over the hills.
1.8: My beloved resembles a gazelle or a young hart; behold, he stands behind our wall, observing through the windows peering through the lattices.
1.9: My beloved spoke and said to me, “Rise up, my beloved, my fair one, and go forth.
1.10: For behold, the winter is past, the rain is over, and gone.
1.11: The blossoms have appeared on the land, the time of singing has come; and the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.
1.12: The fig tree has produced its green figs, and the grapevines tender grapes give out their fragrance; arise my beloved, my fair one, and go forth.
1.13: My dove, in the clefts of the rock, in the concealment of the cliff, show me your countenance, let me hear your voice; for your voice is sweet and your countenance is comely.
1.14: Seize for us the foxes, little foxes that destroy vineyards [for] our vineyards are with tender grapes.”
1.15: My beloved is mine, and I am his, who pastures among the roses.
1.16: Until the sun spreads and the shadows flee; you turned away, my beloved, and became like a gazelle or a young hart on distant mountains.

2.0: On my bed at night, I sought him whom my soul loves; I sought him but did not find him.
2.1: I will rise now and roam through the city, in the market places and in the streets, I will seek him whom my soul loves; I sought him but did not find him.
2.2: The watchmen found me those who circle about the city; him whom my soul loves, have you seen him?
2.3: Scarcely had I departed from them, when I found him whom my soul loves; I grasped him and would not let him go until I brought him to my mother’s house and to the chamber of her who conceived me.
2.4: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim by the gazelles and the does of the field; that you do not cause hatred nor disturb this love while it still pleases.
2.5: Who is this ascending from the wilderness, with palm-like pillars of smoke; in a cloud of myrrh and frankincense, of all the powders of the perfume seller?
2.6: Behold the bed of Shlomo, sixty mighty men are around it; of the mighty men of Yisroel.
2.7: All of them holding swords, skilled in battle; each with his sword at his side for fear of the nights.
2.8: A canopy has King Shlomo made of the wood of Levanon.
2.9: Its pillars he made of silver, its covering of gold, its curtain of purple wool; its interior bedecked with love from the daughters of Yerusholayim.
2.10: Go forth and gaze, daughters of Tzion, upon King Shlomo; upon the crown with which his mother adorned him on the day of his wedding, and on the day his heart rejoiced.

3.0: Behold you are beautiful, my beloved, behold you are beautiful, your eyes are like doves from within your kerchief; your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Mount Gilad.
3.1: Your teeth are like a counted flock which have come up from the washing; all of which are perfect and none are blemished among them.
3.2: Like a scarlet thread are your lips, and your speech is comely; like a slice of pomegranate are your cheeks from within your kerchief.
3.3: Your neck is like the Tower of Dovid, built as a model of beauty; a thousand shields are hung upon it, all the quivers of the mighty.
3.4: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle who pasture among the roses.
3.5: Until the sun spreads and the shadows flee; I will go to Mount Moriyah and to the hill of frankincense.
3.6: You are completely beautiful, my beloved, and you are without blemish.
3.7: With me [will you come] from Levanon O bride, with me from Levanon will you come; you will look from the peak of Amanah, from the peaks of Snir of Chermon, from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of leopards.
3.8: You captured my heart, my sister, O bride; you captured my heart with but one of your eyes, with one necklace of your necklaces.
3.9: How beautiful is your love my sister, O bride; how superior is your love to wine, and the fragrance of your oils to all perfumes.
3.10: Your lips drip flowing honey, O bride; honey and milk are under your tongue, and the fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Levanon.
3.11: A locked garden is my sister, O bride; a locked up spring, a sealed fountain.
3.12: Your arid fields are a pomegranate orchard with luscious fruits; henna with spikenard.
3.13: Spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all the trees of frankincense; myrrh and aloes with all the major spices.
3.14: You are a garden spring, a well of living waters; and flowing streams from Levanon.
3.15: Awake, wind from the north and come, wind from the south, blow upon my garden so that its fragrance may flow; let my beloved come to his garden, and eat its luscious fruit.

4.0: I have come to my garden, my sister, O bride, I have gathered my myrrh with my spice, I have eaten my sugar cane with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk; eat [my] friends, drink and become intoxicated, [my] beloved ones.
4.1: I slept but my heart was awake; a sound! My beloved knocks, open for me, my sister, my love, my dove, my perfection, for my head is drenched [as though] with dew, my sidelocks drip with the rains of the night.
4.2: I have removed my robe, how can I put it on? I have washed my feet, how can I soil them?
4.3: My beloved sent forth his hand from the portal, and my innards longed for him.
4.4: I arose to open for my beloved; and my hands dripped myrrh, and my fingers flowed with myrrh from the handles of the lock.
4.5: I opened for my beloved, but my beloved had vanished and gone; my soul departed as he spoke, I sought him but could not find him, I called him but he would not answer.
4.6: The watchmen found me, those who go about the city, they struck me, they wounded me; they stripped my ornament from me, [even] the guards of the walls.
4.7: I bind you under oath, daughters of Yerusholayim; when you find my beloved, what will you tell him? that I am lovesick [for him.]
4.8: With what does your beloved excel another beloved, most beautiful among women? With what does your beloved excel another beloved, that you bind us under oath?
4.9: My beloved is pure white and ruddy, surrounded by myriads.
4.10: His head is [like] finest gold, his locks hang, they are raven-black.
4.11: His eyes are like doves upon brooks of water; bathed in milk, well set in their fullness.
4.12: His cheeks are like a bed of spice, like towers of perfumes; his lips are like roses, dripping [with] flowing myrrh.
4.13: His hands are like rolls of gold studded with precious gems; his innards sparkle like ivory, overlaid with sapphires.
4.14: His legs are like pillars of marble set in sockets of fine gold; his appearance is like Levanon chosen like the cedars.
4.15: [The words of] his palate are sweet, and he is all delight; this is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Yerusholayim.

5.0: Where has your beloved gone O fairest among women? Where has your beloved turned that we may seek him with you?
5.1: My beloved has gone down to his garden, to the beds of spices; to graze in the gardens and to gather roses.
5.2: I am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine, who grazes among the roses.
5.3: You are beautiful, my beloved, as Tirtzah, comely as Yerusholayim, awesome as the hosts [of angels].
5.4: Turn your eyes away from me, for they made me haughty; your hair is like a flock of goats descending from Mount Gilad.
5.5: Your teeth are like a counted flock which have come up from the washing; all of which are perfect and none are blemished among them.
5.6: Like a slice of pomegranate are your cheeks from within your kerchief.
5.7: There are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and young maidens without number.
5.8: But she is unique, my dove, my perfect one, she is unique to her mother, she is pure to her who begot her; daughters saw her and acclaimed her, queens and concubines, and they praised her.
5.9: Who is this that gazes down like the [breaking] dawn, beautiful as the moon, bright as the sun, awesome as the hosts [of angels]?
5.10: I went down to the garden of nuts, to see the moist plants of the valley; to see whether the vine had blossomed, if the pomegranates had sprouted.
5.11: I did not know, my soul set me like chariots of a noble people.

6.0: Turn back, turn back [you] perfect one, turn back, turn back, that we may observe you; what can you see [offer] the perfect one that equals the encirclement of the camps?
6.1: How fair were your feet in sandals, O daughter of nobles; the roundness of your flanks, are like jewels, the work of a craftsman.
6.2: Your navel is like a round bowl, which lacks not for mixed wines; your stomach is like a heap of wheat, hedged about with roses.
6.3: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.
6.4: Your neck is like an ivory tower; your eyes are like pools in Cheshbon, at the gate of the populated city, your face is like a tower of Levanon looking out as far as Damascus.
6.5: That which is upon your head is like Mount Carmel, and the braid of your head is like [royal] purple wool; your King is bound in its tresses.
6.6: How beautiful and pleasant are you; a love with delights.
6.7: Such is your stature, likened to a [stately] palm tree; and your breasts are like clusters.
6.8: I said, I will ascend the palm tree, I will grasp its branches; and now, let your breasts remain like clusters of the vine, and the fragrance of your face like apples.
6.9: And let your speech be like good wine; it flows for my beloved in sincerity, causing the lips of sleepers to murmur.
6.10: I am my beloved’s and he longs for me.
6.11: Come, my beloved, let us go out to the field, let us lodge in the villages.
6.12: Let us rise early for the vineyards, let us see if the vine has blossomed, if the tender grapes have appeared, if the pomegranates are in bloom; there I will give my love to you.
6.13: The baskets emit fragrance, and at our door are all luscious fruits, both new and old; my beloved, I have kept them for you.

7.0: If only you were a brother to me, who had nursed at my mother’s bosom; when I would find you outside I would kiss you, and no one would scorn me.
7.1: I would lead you, I would bring you to my mother’s house that you should teach me; I would give you spiced wine to drink, of the nectar of my pomegranate.
7.2: His left hand is under my head and his right hand embraces me.
7.3: I bind you under oath daughters of Yerusholayim why should you cause hatred or disturb [this] love while it still pleases?
7.4: Who is she that rises from the wilderness, clinging to her beloved? beneath the apple tree I aroused you, there your mother had birth pains there she who bore you suffered.
7.5: Set me as a seal upon your heart as a seal upon your arm, for love is as strong as death, jealousy is as harsh as the grave; its flashes are flashes of fire from the flame of God.
7.6: Many waters cannot quench the love, and rivers cannot drown it; if a man would give all the wealth of his house for love they would surely scorn him.
7.7: We have a little sister but she has no breasts; what shall we do for our sister on the day she is spoken for?
7.8: If she be a wall we will build upon her a fortress of silver, if she be a door, we will enclose her with panels of cedar.
7.9: I am a wall and my bosom is like towers; therefore I am in his eyes as one who found peace.
7.10: Shlomo had a vineyard in the Plain of Hamon, he gave over the vineyard to caretakers; each of them brought for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
7.11: My vineyard is before me; the thousand are yours, Shlomo, and two hundred are for those who guard its fruit.
7.12: You who sit in the gardens, companions listen to your voice, let me hear [your voice].
7.13: Flee my beloved and be like a gazelle or a young hart upon the mountains of spices.
